This vacuum mechanism doesn't exactly work the same in space as on Earth. On Earth the atmospheric pressure, weather changes ignored, stays constant because it's a result of the gravity of Earth. In space, the atmosphere is in an enclosed container, so by pulling the cylinder, you're compressing the air in the spaceship. That will increase the pressure in the space ship. OK, maybe not significantly, but it's the same issue as the spring and the rubber band. The solution isn't because of constant atmospheric pressure but because the change in pressure is insignificant. You could do the same thing with a really long rubber band.

Osteoclasts are cells that breakdown unused/old bone matrix. When broken down it’s reabsorbed back into the blood, filtered in the kidneys, and excreted. This is how that calcium ends up in urine! On the opposite side of this process are osteoblasts which are cells that form the bone matrix. When the nerves inside your bones sense extra pressure they send signals to your brain to stimulate these cells to form new bone to create reinforcement! This is why exercise is important. There’s a lot of other things that happen along with this such as the activation of hormones and what happens in the kidneys, but this is a pretty general idea!

Typical NASA over-engineering.  That beast is both huge and massive.  A multi-turn torsion spring (like in a roll-up garage door) takes nearly constant force over a wide range of motion, and is much simpler and lighter.  Also, you say that the vacuum exerts a constant force, but that's not true.  You're not really "pulling" the vacuum; you're actually compressing the air in the entire spacecraft with that piston.  Remember, the spacecraft is a closed system.  I'm sure that in something the size of the ISS, that's a microscopic fraction of the total volume, but in a smaller capsule that could be felt by the people not using the machine.

Burning the astronaut pee is basically a scaled-up version of the "flame test" you do in high school science. Specific elements burn with specific emission spectra. Like copper compounds, they burn with a bluish-green flame. Although with this test they're actually using the absorption characteristics of the same flame to figure out the exact "energy gap" for the electron transition for whatever they're burning - and because those are specific to each element, if they get that data they figure out what they're burning.

Hey Destin, love your videos.
Here's a fun story. I did a PhD at Oxford University in Palaeobiology, studying how billion-year old fossils of cells are preserved in the rocks of Scotland. Those fossils were preserved in a form of calcium phosphate.
At that time, I also a a brief flirtation with astrobiology, and the combination of my skills and interests led me to NASA Ames, where I conducted an investigation into the ability of various modern algae to mediate the precipitation of calcium phosphate. The relevance? Calcium phosphate is what makes up our bones. As you found out, the calcium is lost through our pee, so I helped to lay down a theoretical basis for a way of reclaiming that loss. Take astronaut pee, run it over a bed of these algae, where it will precipitate out. Collect that precipitate and form it into pills, take those pills, and boom, you get calcium phosphate back in your system. Cool huh?

Weightlessness and it's effects on our bodies is the first barrier to our greater exploration of space. Right now, we're just sitting on the dock, dangling our toes in the water. It's like the moon-landing astronauts had a kayak, but went out for an hour and came back. Space station astronauts are wading up to their ankles, but otherwise, we've never left "the shore" of earth.

If we ever go anywhere off this planet, knowing all of this, and knowing how to live despite it (until we get to another earth-gravity place), means, someday, we will have one thing about space travel overcome.

The astronaut pee burning device is called a mass spectrometer. When I was stationed aboard the Carl Vinson, a much larger version was used to test oil samples. By vaporizing the oil, in this case a carbon ark was used instead of a flame, shining a laser through it, and re directing it with mirrors, through a prism, and on to a bank of light sensitive tubes, it would produce a graph showing the concentrations of metals in the oil. This technique only requires that you know the various patterns created by the materials you wish to test for. I actually asked the operator of this particular mass spectrometer if he had ever tested his pee... He had.

So, burning the urine is essentially the same way aviation and industrial Q/A or labs use the Oil Analysis machines via the atomic emission spectroscopy principle. By burning the substance (oil or urine) in a controlled light source (GREEN FLAME...for all you DND fans) or an electric arc via a carbon rod, each individual chemical/element can be measured, regardless of size, and give an accurate reading of the contents within the liquid. However, for oil analysis, it isn't necessary to dilute it. I was surprised she had to dilute the urine 100/1.

I'm really surprised that they would utilize this type of technology in bodily fluids. I wonder if the applications that be used in blood or brain tissue to get more accurate readings for those with kidney failure or in the analysis of Alzheimers.

08:33 That should be a flame atomizer which can be used to detect calcium atoms.

To do this the sample is dried and transferred into a gaseous phase. This gaseous phase (aerosol) is then mixed with the flame gases and introduced to the flame. The flame has a very high temperature (typically around 2000-3000 °C) which dissociates all molecules into free atoms. The calcium ions have a specific wavelength of light which they absorb, so they can be detected with the help of a light beam and a detector.
